title: 107_hr3218
content: The "Abandoned Mine Land Area Redevelopment Act of 2001" allows for a credit to holders of qualified abandoned mine land area redevelopment bonds under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Abandoned Mine Land Area Redevelopment Act of 2001" provides a tax credit to taxpayers holding qualified abandoned mine land area redevelopment bonds under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit amount is 25 percent of the annual credit determined for each bond. The bond's credit amount is determined by multiplying the applicable credit rate with the outstanding face amount of the bond. The applicable credit rate is based on the average market yield on outstanding long-term corporate debt obligations. There is a special rule for bonds issued within a 3-month period, where the credit amount is a ratable portion of the total credit. The credit amount of a bond is determined by multiplying the credit rate with the face amount. A special rule applies to bonds issued within a 3-month period. Qualified abandoned mine land area redevelopment bonds have specific criteria for issuance. The national volume cap for approved special purpose entities is $20,000,000,000, with a minimum allocation of $2,000,000,000. Bonds issued must not exceed 30 years in term, and only \1/6\ of the net proceeds can be deposited into a sinking fund. The maximum aggregate face amount of bonds designated by an entity is limited by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. The approved special purpose entity must have a comprehensive plan approved by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. $2,000,000,000 is allocated to an entity focusing on abandoned mine land areas with anthracite coal. The "segregated program fund" must have safeguards approved by the Administrator to ensure funds are used for qualified purposes. The tax credit for any taxable year is limited by the regular tax liability and other allowable credits. Unused credits can be carried over to future years. The tax credit for any taxable year exceeding the limitation can be carried over to the succeeding taxable year. Definitions for "abandoned mine land areas" and "qualified purpose" are provided for redevelopment bonds. The curr_chunk outlines the purposes for which abandoned mine land redevelopment bonds can be used, including purchase, restoration, cleanup of waterways, infrastructure assistance, research, and other environmental and economic development projects. These purposes are set forth in a comprehensive plan prepared by the issuer. The curr_chunk explains the credit allowance dates for abandoned mine land redevelopment bonds and defines terms like "credit allowance date" and "bond." It also mentions that gross income includes the credit allowed to the taxpayer and that bonds held by regulated investment companies are subject to specific rules. The qualified abandoned mine land area redevelopment bond credit can be allowed to shareholders of a regulated investment company. The ownership of the bond and entitlement to the credit can be separated, with the credit going to the holder of the entitlement instrument. The rules of section 1286 apply to the qualified abandoned mine land area redevelopment bond as a stripped bond. The credit under this section is treated as a stripped coupon for estimated tax purposes. The credit allowed by this section can be transferred through sale and repurchase agreements. Issuers of these bonds must submit reports similar to those required under section 149(e). The rules of section 1286 apply to the qualified abandoned mine land area redevelopment bond as a stripped bond. Issuers of these bonds must submit reports similar to those required under section 149(e). The section shall not apply to any bond issued more than 10 years after the date that the first qualified abandoned mine land area redevelopment bond is issued. Reporting requirements for interest on qualified abandoned mine land area redevelopment bonds are specified in subsection (d) of section 6049 of the Code. The Secretary shall prescribe regulations for reporting requirements on interest described in subparagraph (A) of this paragraph, disregarding certain subparagraphs. The Secretary of the Treasury must issue regulations for qualified abandoned mine land area redevelopment bonds within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency must approve any requests related to these bonds within 60 days of submission. The amendments apply to obligations issued after December 31, 2001.
